title: Social media users share their savvy hotel hacks for making the most of your stay
text:
A hotel curtain hack that went viral has quickly sparked thousands of savvy social media users to share their own nifty tips and tricks.

Rick Klau, from California, revealed a hotel hack on Twitter for creating 'blackout' curtains using a coat hanger.

His tweet quickly went viral as thousands praised his 'ingenious' move, inspiring others to share their own tips and tricks for making the most out of staying in a hotel.

One commented: 'My hotel hack is if you ever need an extra phone charger, ask the front desk if they found one. They have a box full.'

Rick Klau, from California, delighted social media users when he revealed his hotel hack online

This came after Rick shared a snap of his adapted 'blackout' curtain in a now-viral tweet online.

He tweeted: 'I don't remember who posted this on Twitter a few years ago, but whoever you are: you have improved every night I've spent in a hotel since.

His tweet received 390k likes, and inspired hundreds of others to share their own hotel hacks.

One posted: 'I always bring a 10' LAN cable and plug my laptop directly into the wireless router.'

Rick shared a snap of his handy tip online and it quickly went viral, with over 390k likes on Twitter

Rick shared his helpful hack online in a now-viral tweet as he revealed he had been making blackout blinds with the help of a coat hanger

Another wrote: 'I use the clip on the hotel pen but the hanger looks more effective!'

'And put the chair back in front of the A/C to stop it blowing directly on you,' another commented.

One added: 'Best hotel hack: Instead of touching the disgusting TV remote, wrap it in the shower cap.'

Others were quick to share their own hotel hacks, from grabbing free water to repurposing ironing boards

Another wrote: 'Total travel code along with grabbing free waters at the hotel gym.'

One added: 'My favourite hotel hack: Your ironing board is an adjustable height desk.

'Since the chairs are never the right height, use the ironing board for long hotel work.'
description: Rick Klau, from California, shared his helpful hack on how to create make-shift blackout blinds in a hotel room in a now-viral tweet. Many praised him for the ingenious move and shared their own tips.
